title: On Monday Night Football, Jose Mourinho, Gary Neville, Roy Keane and Sky Sports' drive towards reality TV
text:
It’s 20 years ago last month that Big Brother first aired, initially in the Netherlands, then the UK, before the virus promptly went airborne to create a global franchise. Dutch media tycoon John de Mol’s reality show, and the genre it ushered in, were either a fascinating new use of television as a medium, or a miserable staging post in our cultural decline, depending on your view. But what is undeniable is that TV companies loved and continue to cherish a reality show. They’re cheap to make, advertisers covet the viewer demographic, they are scalable, and they often get enormous free exposure in other media outlets or social media.

Live sport, in many senses, is reality television’s antithesis:...
description: It’s 20 years ago last month that Big Brother first aired, initially in the Netherlands, then the UK, before the virus promptly went airborne to create a global franchise.
